(1 comment)

no its not 

why is this not under /var/lib/user_mgr??  THe FHS specifies the label should be a package or related packages; mfa is a feature 

see https://refspecs.linuxfoundation.org/FHS_2.3/fhs-2.3.pdf section 5.8
Acknowledged
just a quick glance and found an error and a question

D-Bus signals generally used for communication between applications, allows one D-bus app to notify each other about important events or changes.

In this case, The D-bus app itself monitoring its own D-bus signals which I never seen in any OpenBMC apps.

Since its the same D-bus app which knows about D-bus property changes, this can be achieved without monitoring D-bus signals as well.
I agree that it works functionally but we need to check if there any corner cases where D-bus signals missed..

This is to avoid spreading serialisation call though out the code whenever there is a change in properties. Otherwise we should be add the code for all property set functions and in some cases we may unnecessarily overrides the property setting function just for serialising it.

I don't see any reason we miss signals for pesistable properties. If misses it is bug in property handling not in serialisation code.
we also need to check if its causing any performance bottleneck or any event loop issues for this D-bus app when there are multiple property change signals generated.
I dont see any performance issue in my testing. What event loop issue are you anticipating? Can you explain a bit more how it can happen?
You cannot monitor your own application's signals.  There is no guarantee of delivery.

But it worked. If it does not work always ,isn't it a signal implementation bug?
An application may have multiple objects. If one wanted to monitor other's property changes what is the best way then?. Are you suggesting that create a circular dependency between the objects instead?.

monitoring your own object is prohibited 
this is to avoid deadlocks 

if it t works sometimes it's due to slack buffering.

this must be fixed.
Could you clarify? Are you saying that every DBus application is inherently multi-threaded? Also, could you elaborate on the deadlock scenario?
"/var/lib/mfa-conf/usr_mgr.conf"
done

I think "libs" is a typo here.

Having a random file in `/var/lib` certainly doesn't match our convention.  Please put this under `/var/lib/phosphor-user-manager` at a minimum.

Why doesn't this have anything related to MFA in the file name?
as written this patch is too complex to tell from the code what it's trying to accomplish.
std::format seems like overkill here.  don't these already have their own types?
Acknowledged
please don't write lambdas more than a line or two.
Acknowledged
Why are you not using the sdbusplus match helpers?
I was not aware of it when I wrote it.

I'm sure this is all super fancy code, but it is completely unreadable and without a single comment as to what it's purpose even is.

I see you're doing JSON things.  But you're not using any of the "normal" serialization overloads that nlohmann-json expects.  Why not?

https://json.nlohmann.me/features/arbitrary_types/#basic-usage

+1.  This is a lot of fancy code that honestly could be replaced pretty simply with the Nlohmann struct -> json helpers, or manual code.  Even IF we wrote it all by hand manually, and it was more code, which I'm not sure it would be, it would still be readable.

I have seen lots of repos trying to migrate from one serialisation format to another.Keeping that in mind I thought it would be nicer if we does not expose the underlying sterilisation format to the service object. Putting it behind a serialise/deserialise apis will benefit future format changes. I did not try to invent any new API signature for it. Just wanted follow what has been done in other place (for eg: https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/redfish-core/include/utils/json_utils.hpp#L698) .
I know this is an overkill for this repo. But intent is to generalise this and recommend it for a wider usage.   
Second idea is, I wanted to avoid spreading serialise calls to all property setter methods. Now if a property need to be serialised, one has to reimplement setter method for it. I thought using Dbus signal notification can be used to do the serialisation in single place(which does not look good at present). Ideally the dbusplus binding code generator can help here. A 'serialisable' meta attribute in the interface definition file for property and a new Serialisable interface can help here. Then the property setter implementation can be modified to check if the object has serialisable interface then call searialise on it by passing the property name and value.
